heading: physicists tie the knot
subheading: a couple of cambridge university physicists use mathematical models to map the four most common necktie knots -- and come up with six new ones.
author: reuters
text: london -- two british physicists have solved a knotty problem that men have wrestled with for more than a century now. how does one tie the perfect tie? using a mathematical model, thomas fink and yong mao of cambridge university's cavendish laboratory produced equations to classify the four most common ways to knot a tie and introduced six new "aesthetically pleasing" knots."it hasn't been done before," mao said. "we've done extensive searches in literature and on the internet and we haven't found anything like it."the research, published in the science journal nature, said 85 knots could be tied with a conventional tie but only four -- the four-in-hand, the windsor, the half-windsor, and the pratt -- were commonly used.fink and mao classified the knots according to their size and shape and used a triangular lattice, a network of intersecting routes, to represent different knot-tying sequences.by taking "random walks" along the lattice routes they devised mathematical formulas for the knots."a random walk is a concept for polymers in statistical mechanics. it is basically a path than can be analyzed mathematically," mao explained.the simplest knot is the four-in-hand, which originated in england in the late 19th century. the duke of windsor, who abdicated the throne in 1936 for the american divorcee wallis simpson, is credited with introducing the windsor knot. the half-windsor is a simpler version of the duke's knot.the newest knot, until now, was the pratt, which appeared in 1989. the shape of a knot depends on the number of right, center, and left moves in the tie sequence. a balanced knot is tightly bound and keeps its shape.the physicists were surprised by the number of knots that could be made with a tie but many did not pass the aesthetic test of symmetry and balance.they are not sure how their new, and as yet unnamed, knots will be received."it comes down to a matter of personal taste," mao said. "some people are lazy and are happy with just one knot, and some people might be a bit more discerning and try new ones. we simply suggest these are quite nice and pleasant looking."copyright
